headline: US software stocks tumble sparks concerns that AI trade is reshaping markets
summary: The software and services industry's recent plunge has ignited fears that the artificial intelligence boom may be reshaping markets in unexpected ways, raising questions about whether a rotation out of technology stocks signals trouble ahead for ​the AI trade.  Financial markets, juiced for months with investor enthusiasm about the artificial intelligence trade, got a rude awakening last week as software stocks around ‌the globe sank on worries that fast-advancing AI tools could upend the industry.  While a rebound in the broader market helped soothe nerves on Friday, the outlook for U.S. software stocks, at the epicenter of the ‌selloff, remained murky.

content.title: US software stocks tumble sparks concerns that AI trade is reshaping markets
content.summary: The software and services industry's recent plunge has ignited fears that the artificial intelligence boom may be reshaping markets in unexpected ways, raising questions about whether a rotation out of technology stocks signals trouble ahead for ​the AI trade.  Financial markets, juiced for months with investor enthusiasm about the artificial intelligence trade, got a rude awakening last week as software stocks around ‌the globe sank on worries that fast-advancing AI tools could upend the industry.  While a rebound in the broader market helped soothe nerves on Friday, the outlook for U.S. software stocks, at the epicenter of the ‌selloff, remained murky.

headline: Alphabet Looks to Raise About $15 Billion From US Bond Sale
summary: Just last week, Oracle Corp. raised $25 billion from a bond that attracted a record $129 billion of orders at its peak.  Alphabet didn’t immediately respond to a comment request.  JPMorgan Chase & Co., Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and Bank of America Corp., which are helping manage the US dollar bond sale, declined to comment.

JPMorgan Chase & Co., Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and Bank of America Corp., which are helping manage the US dollar bond sale, declined to comment.

headline: Transform Shared Service Organization Improves EHR Performance and Drives AI Adoption with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure
summary: The five hospitals supported by Transform Shared Service Organization (TSSO) in Ontario, Canada, have improved the performance, usability, and availability of their Oracle Health Foundation electronic health record (EHR) by migrating it to Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI). With OCI, the hospitals can enhance the experience for patients and clinicians, scale efficiently, and easily adopt new AI-powered technologies, such as a recently launched pilot of Oracle Health Clinical AI Agent.

content.title: Transform Shared Service Organization Improves EHR Performance and Drives AI Adoption with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure
content.summary: The five hospitals supported by Transform Shared Service Organization (TSSO) in Ontario, Canada, have improved the performance, usability, and availability of their Oracle Health Foundation electronic health record (EHR) by migrating it to Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI). With OCI, the hospitals can enhance the experience for patients and clinicians, scale efficiently, and easily adopt new AI-powered technologies, such as a recently launched pilot of Oracle Health Clinical AI Agent.

headline: Alphabet Is Selling 100-Year Debt as Part of a Big Bond Sale
summary: Alphabet is gearing up to sell bonds that won't come due for a century, as it becomes the second big tech company to tap the bond market this year after Oracle issued $25 billion of debt a week ago.  The Google parent plans to sell debt in dollars, British pounds and Swiss francs with varying maturities, according to an investor familiar with the matter.  Alphabet and Oracle are among a handful of tech companies that have started borrowing heavily to fund massive investments in artificial-intelligence infrastructure.

content.title: Alphabet Is Selling 100-Year Debt as Part of a Big Bond Sale
content.summary: Alphabet is gearing up to sell bonds that won't come due for a century, as it becomes the second big tech company to tap the bond market this year after Oracle issued $25 billion of debt a week ago.  The Google parent plans to sell debt in dollars, British pounds and Swiss francs with varying maturities, according to an investor familiar with the matter.  Alphabet and Oracle are among a handful of tech companies that have started borrowing heavily to fund massive investments in artificial-intelligence infrastructure.

headline: Larry Ellison, Jeff Bezos Lose $66B as AI Slump Triggers Tech Billionaire Wealth Rout
summary: The tech industry witnessed a dramatic shift as the wealth of several top tech billionaires plummeted due to fears over the AI bubble and fluctuating valuations. Larry Ellison, co-founder of Oracle, experienced a staggering $59.2 billion loss in his net worth since the beginning of the year, with $19 billion of that occurring just this week. The selloff was exacerbated by developments such as Anthropic’s new legal AI tool, which caused a nearly 4% drop in the S&P 500 software and services index.

content.title: Larry Ellison, Jeff Bezos Lose $66B as AI Slump Triggers Tech Billionaire Wealth Rout
content.summary: The tech industry witnessed a dramatic shift as the wealth of several top tech billionaires plummeted due to fears over the AI bubble and fluctuating valuations. Larry Ellison, co-founder of Oracle, experienced a staggering $59.2 billion loss in his net worth since the beginning of the year, with $19 billion of that occurring just this week. The selloff was exacerbated by developments such as Anthropic’s new legal AI tool, which caused a nearly 4% drop in the S&P 500 software and services index.

headline: Oracle Stock Gets Boost From Analyst Upgrade
summary: Oracle shares gained 11% Monday, poised for their biggest daily rise since September, after an analyst wrote that investors should see the software company in a more positive light now that OpenAI's funding runway looks clearer.  "We believe OpenAI already has as much as $40B of cash on hand and may be raising as much as another $100B by the end of the quarter, which should help pay for the data centers Oracle is building for OpenAI," wrote D.A. Davidson analyst Gil Luria, who upgraded the stock to buy.

content.title: Oracle Stock Gets Boost From Analyst Upgrade
content.summary: Oracle shares gained 11% Monday, poised for their biggest daily rise since September, after an analyst wrote that investors should see the software company in a more positive light now that OpenAI's funding runway looks clearer.  "We believe OpenAI already has as much as $40B of cash on hand and may be raising as much as another $100B by the end of the quarter, which should help pay for the data centers Oracle is building for OpenAI," wrote D.A. Davidson analyst Gil Luria, who upgraded the stock to buy.

headline: Oracle Shares Surge as Big Tech Spending Eases Software Worries
summary: “Software isn’t dead,” D.A. Davidson analyst Gil Luria wrote in a note, upgrading the stock to buy from neutral.  Worries that AI will hurt demand for software products have slammed the sector in recent weeks, taking the IShares Expanded Tech-Software Sector exchange-traded fund down some 28% from its highs.  While those concerns are unlikely to disappear, some are betting that at least some of the about $650 billion in spending for AI tools from Amazon, Alphabet Inc., Meta Platforms Inc. and Microsoft Corp. will flow to software companies.

content.title: Oracle Shares Surge as Big Tech Spending Eases Software Worries
content.summary: “Software isn’t dead,” D.A. Davidson analyst Gil Luria wrote in a note, upgrading the stock to buy from neutral.  Worries that AI will hurt demand for software products have slammed the sector in recent weeks, taking the IShares Expanded Tech-Software Sector exchange-traded fund down some 28% from its highs.  While those concerns are unlikely to disappear, some are betting that at least some of the about $650 billion in spending for AI tools from Amazon, Alphabet Inc., Meta Platforms Inc. and Microsoft Corp. will flow to software companies.

headline: Oracle’s Bets on OpenAI, TikTok Will Pay Off. Buy the Stock, This Analyst Says.
summary: Oracle  stock has had a rough few months, and now may be time to buy the dip, according to analysts at D.A. Davidson.  The firm upgraded Oracle shares to Buy from Neutral and maintained its price target of $180 in a research note Monday.  The fate of the stock is heavily tied to OpenAI—and, to a lesser extent, TikTok—but those relationships could pay off, D.A. Davidson says.

content.title: Oracle’s Bets on OpenAI, TikTok Will Pay Off. Buy the Stock, This Analyst Says.
content.summary: Oracle  stock has had a rough few months, and now may be time to buy the dip, according to analysts at D.A. Davidson.  The firm upgraded Oracle shares to Buy from Neutral and maintained its price target of $180 in a research note Monday.  The fate of the stock is heavily tied to OpenAI—and, to a lesser extent, TikTok—but those relationships could pay off, D.A. Davidson says.

headline: Alphabet's debt raise fuels forecasts for record year in corporate bond sales
summary: Google parent Alphabet tapped the U.S. high-grade bond market on Monday, adding to a boom in debt funding by AI companies that analysts project will lead ​to a record-breaking year for corporate debt issuance.  The company is planning an additional debut sterling offering which could include a rare 100-year bond, ‌according to a report on Monday by the Financial Times, which cited people familiar with the matter.  Alphabet did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

content.title: Alphabet's debt raise fuels forecasts for record year in corporate bond sales
content.summary: Google parent Alphabet tapped the U.S. high-grade bond market on Monday, adding to a boom in debt funding by AI companies that analysts project will lead ​to a record-breaking year for corporate debt issuance.  The company is planning an additional debut sterling offering which could include a rare 100-year bond, ‌according to a report on Monday by the Financial Times, which cited people familiar with the matter.  Alphabet did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
